title: San Serif metal letters
content:
This might be a stretch of a request. These are metal letters used to identify the building I live in. It looks like it could be Helvetica, but I figured some of you on here could point out why it's NOT Helvetica. I appreciate any help!

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20141008121849im_/http:/typophile.com/files/2014-10-03%2008_5034.03.24.jpg)
author: TheCyclist

comments.content:
Q: "why it's NOT Helvetica."  
A: At least five letters, \_G\_ with no spur, \_R\_ with straight leg, and \_C\_, \_D\_ and \_O\_ with a vertical section in the curved strokes. The letter \_S\_ could pass for Helvetica, Arial etc.  
The letters have some similarities to DIN, except for the \_S\_.  
Might not be a standard font.  
Don
These letters look like they were probably made by architects or engineers, not type designers. My bet is not a font.

Agree with all previous comments. I tried to gather some fonts that could mimic this lettering and focus my search on "DIN-like with Helvetica-ish /S". Here are the ones I ended up with: [Pilcrow](http://web.archive.org/web/20141008121849/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/indian-type-foundry/pilcrow) ITF, Brownfox [Brutal](http://web.archive.org/web/20141008121849/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/brownfox/brutal-type) and [Institut](http://web.archive.org/web/20141008121849/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/brownfox/institut), [Predige](http://web.archive.org/web/20141008121849/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/typedynamic/predige), [Neusa](http://web.archive.org/web/20141008121849/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/northernblock/neusa), 4F [Bond](http://web.archive.org/web/20141008121849/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/4thfebruary/bond-4f) and [Meeneralca](http://web.archive.org/web/20141008121849/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/4thfebruary/meeneralca-4f), [Hill](http://web.archive.org/web/20141008121849/http:/typophile.com/wiki/https%3A/%252Fplaytype.com/index.php%3Fq%3Dfont/hill), [Dillon](http://web.archive.org/web/20141008121849/http:/www.fontsmith.com/fonts/fs-dillon) FS, [Palestina](http://web.archive.org/web/20141008121849/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/tipo/palestina), [Technik](http://web.archive.org/web/20141008121849/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/carnoky/technik)
